awd_titl_txt: Electricity Generation and Enhanced Heat Transfer via Pulsating Ferro-Nanofluid
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1403872
Thompson

New methods for harvesting waste energy can allow for reduced fossil fuel-dependence, off-grid power generation and more efficient vehicles and buildings. Traditional thermoelectric materials can be used for these applications; however, their use is limited due to their relatively low thermal conductivities and low melting temperatures. The proposed research project centers on a new thermal-to-electrical energy harvesting/conversion method comprised of a capillary-sized heat pipe filled with magnetic fluid that operates via temperature difference. When the magnetic fluid inside the oscillating heat pipe (OHP) is exposed to a solenoid, an electrical alternating-current is generated. The high thermal conductivity and temperature stability of OHPs will allow for their utilization in conditions and applications where traditional thermoelectric materials are not viable. This new waste-heat recovery process will provide a new method for energy recovery and thermal management in a wide range of energy efficient applications.

The project's research objective is to better understand "thermofluidic induction" a unique thermo-kinetic-electromagnetic energy conversion process inherent to temperature-driven flow of magnetic nanofluid near a solenoid which can result in heat transfer enhancement and electrical power generation. Well-designed experiments on various OHP platforms will be conducted to determine the influence of the design and operating parameters on the performance of these OHPs in terms of heat flux and electrical power generation. Various nanofluids will be synthesized and then characterized using a wide range of techniques, including dynamic light scattering (DLS), atomic force microscopy (AFM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), in order to determine their physical and thermal characteristics before and after OHP-operation. The effects of thermal fatigue and nanoparticle settling will be studied. A transparent OHP will also be constructed to better understand the extent to which the nanofluid and OHP operating parameters affect energy harvesting, fluid mechanics and heat transfer. Thermo-kinetic-electromagnetic modeling will be accomplished by utilizing and modifying available multiphysics software on select OHP models. The research objectives are to determine: (1) the extent to which the magnetic field and heat transfer are coupled in thermally-driven, pulsating capillary flow of ferro-nanofluid near a solenoid, (2) how to effectively transfer heat and/or generate a magnetic field in an oscillating heat pipe by varying specific design parameters, (3) the extent to which thermally-driven, pulsating capillary flows of ferro-nanofluids can: (i) enhance heat transfer and/or (ii) affect nanoparticle suspendability (agglomeration) and particle size/distribution (i.e. thermal fatigue of nanofluids) and finally (4) a novel, multiphysics analytical/numerical model that aids in predicting heat transfer and electrical power generation inherent to thermofluidic induction.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
In this project a combination of equipment design and development, nanomaterial synthesis and characterization, and mathematical modeling were used to examine an energy-conversion process.  Temperature differences were used to create pulses or oscillations in ferrofluids (magnetic nanoparticle suspended in a carrier fluid) within a magnetic field and these pulses generated voltage using a solenoid.  By combining experimental and theoretical analyses, the project provided a better understanding of the primary operational parameters and material properties that impact this energy conversion process. The energy harvesting process was demonstrated using a solenoid flow loop pumping system and an oscillating heat pipe (OHP) charged with ferrofluid as the working fluid, and data from these demonstrations were used to validate an analytical model of electromagnetic induction in pulsating ferrofluid flows.  Additionally, this project involved educational and professional development opportunities for multiple faculty and students—including post-doctoral fellows, PhD and MS students, and undergraduate researchers—from three fields and four institutions. This project provided the student researchers with a unique opportunity to work in a highly-interdisciplinary, team-based and perform research in diverse lab settings.

Key project outcomes are summarized below:

(I)             Two experimental testing rigs were designed and built to carry out electromagnetic induction in pulsating ferrofluid flows. Experiments were carried out in a pumped flow loop and oscillating heat pipe—both outfitted bias magnets to create a magnetic field to align the nanoparticle and in-line solenoid for voltage generation.   

(II)           An analytical model for predicting voltage generation of a pulsating, isothermal ferrofluid across a solenoid has been developed and validated using the experimental data from (I). 

(III)         Ferrous oxide (Fe3O4) and cobalt-ferrite (CoFe2O4) nanoparticles were synthesized and surface modified with remain stable in aqueous solutions, even with large thermal cycles and phase changes

(IV)         Student researchers (1 post-doctoral fellow and 3 graduate students) were trained in scientific methods, project management, communication skills and conducting multi-disciplinary scientific research.

(V)          Findings from this project were presented in several technical conferences and published in peer-reviewed journals.

 


Last Modified: 11/14/2018
Modified by: Keisha Walters

Images (1 of )
  • Within a magnetic field, dipoles of magnetic nanoparticles (MNP) align and can form larger-scale structures. Analytical model developed describes the impact of magnetic nanoparticle properties, magnetic field, hydrodynamics, oscillation frequency, and MNP structure size on solenoid output voltages.
    Keisha Walters

    Analytical Model Results for Induced Voltage Generation in Oscillating Flow Through Solenoid Flow Loop
  • CFD two-phase simulation of thermosiphon with evaporation, adiabatic and condensation zones.
    Huiyu Wang
    Copyrighted
    Keisha Walters
    Thermosiphon CFD
  • Schematic of oscillating heat pipe (OHP) experimental design for testing the impact of aqueous ferrofluid as the working fluid. Solenoid for energy harvesting from oscillations of aligned ferrofluids in magnetic field shown on one leg of the OHP.
    Gabriel Monroe
    Copyrighted
    Keisha Walters
    Ferrofluid Oscillating Heat Pipe (FF-OHP)
  • Flow loop with energy harvesting solenoid to experimentally measure the impact of magnetic field strength and oscillation frequency on induced electromotive force (EMF).
    Gabriel Monroe
    Copyrighted
    Keisha Walters
    Ferrofluid Solenoid Flow Loop Experimental Design
  • Impact of number and spacing of bias magnet, as well as the use of ferrofluid vs. water, on the peak-to-peak voltages measured from the solenoid of the flow loop experiment.
    Gabriel Monroe
    Keisha Walters
    Solenoid Flow Loop Experimental Data Summary
